channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: E.U. Agrees to a Price Cap for Sale of Russian Oil
item.description: Following protracted negotiations, European Union diplomats set a price limit of $60 a barrel that they and their allies will try to enforce for buyers of Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: How a German State Helped Russia Complete Nord Stream 2
item.description: The threat of U.S. sanctions jeopardized completion of a second direct gas pipeline from Russia. So Gazprom and German officials concocted a phony climate foundation to get the job done.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pipes from Nord Stream 2 work in Sassnitz, Germany. Russia invaded Ukraine weeks after the pipeline was finished.

item.title: A Drummer Showing the Way to ‘the Freest Musical Universe’
item.description: Miguel Tomasín, one of the few professional musicians with Down syndrome, has brought attention to the artistic visions of people with developmental disabilities, with his band releasing over 100 albums.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Anita Pouchard Serra
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miguel Tomasín has released more than 100 albums with his band, Reynols.

item.title: How China’s Police Used Phones and Faces to Track Protesters
item.description: After a weekend of protests, the authorities in China are using the country’s all-seeing surveillance apparatus to find those bold enough to defy them.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Claire Fu and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: People protesting in Beijing in November after a vigil for the victims of an apartment fire in Urumqi, China.

item.title: Under Pressure, South Africa’s President Snubs Party’s Leadership
item.description: In the face of possible impeachment, Cyril Ramaphosa has not been seen since the release of a damning report. But his allies are urging him to fight back and remain in office.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa during a news conference in London, last month.

item.title: Canadian Man Charged in Rebecca Contois's Murder Accused of 3 More Killings
item.description: The suspect was accused of killing three Indigenous women and another unidentified woman, all of whom had gone missing in Winnipeg.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: John Woods/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Relatives and friends of three murdered women, including Morgan Harris, gathered at a vigil in Winnipeg.

item.title: Pakistan Condemns ‘Assassination Attempt’ on Its Kabul Embassy
item.description: The gunfire, which critically injured one security guard, comes amid increased tensions between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Taliban security forces in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Friday, near the site of an attack on the Pakistani embassy.

item.title: After Xi’s Coronation, a Roar of Discontent Against His Hard-Line Politics
item.description: Protests in China have roused a tradition of dissent that had seemed spent after 10 years under Xi Jinping. The effects may far outlast the street clashes.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Police cordoning off part of a street at a protest against China’s “zero-Covid” measures in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: China Appears to Loosen Covid Rules After Protests
item.description: Several cities announced the easing of lockdown regulations and testing requirements after the country’s biggest demonstrations in decades.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Chang Che
item.media:description: Vigil attendees in Beijing on Sunday holding white sheets of paper during a commemoration of the victims of a fire in Urumqi, China. The paper represents silent opposition to the country’s Covid-19 restrictions.

item.title: Prosecutor Drops Australia Parliament Rape Case, Citing Toll on Accuser
item.description: Mental trauma that Brittany Higgins faced from the proceedings presented a “significant and unacceptable risk” to her life, the prosecutor said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The defendant, Bruce Lehrmann, leaving court in Canberra, Australia, in October.

item.title: U.S. and Ukrainian Embassies Targeted by Letter Bombs in Spain
item.description: One of the six packages containing “pyrotechnic material” was also sent to the prime minister’s office in Madrid, prompting the authorities to increase security.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista, Isabella Kwai and John Ismay
item.media:description: Security officers outside the Ministry of Defense in Madrid on Thursday. The Spanish police were said to be analyzing the packages for fingerprints and DNA.

item.title: Can Neymar and Brazil’s World Cup Team Unite a Fractured Nation?
item.description: Brazil’s World Cup team has become a political lightning rod at home after an ugly election. A championship might be the only thing that can bring Brazil together.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazilian fans wore the classic yellow team jerseys, but also blue and white variations as they gathered in Rio de Janeiro’s beachside Copacabana neighborhood last week to watch their team’s first game at the World Cup.

item.title: The French Baguette Is Granted UNESCO World Heritage Status
item.description: More than six billion baguettes are sold every year in France. But the bread is under threat, with bakeries vanishing in rural areas.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France described the baguette as “250 grams of magic and perfection in our daily lives.”

item.title: An Agonizing Wait for a Migrant Worker’s Final Journey Home
item.description: The inequality and vulnerability that laborers from places like Nepal face overseas also stalk them in death, when dreams evaporate.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Bhadra Sharma and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: The funeral for Rakesh Kumar Yadav, a 40-year-old Nepali who died three months after arriving in Dubai to work as a security guard.

item.title: U.S. Sees Little Prospect for Ukraine Talks With Putin After Biden Offer
item.description: The Kremlin reaffirmed a stance that both Washington and Kyiv find unacceptable, and U.S. officials said Mr. Biden’s position had not changed.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Switzerland last year.

item.title: As Macron Loses His Sheen at Home, Harmonious U.S. Visit Is ‘Regenerative’
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron, dealing with a difficult start to his second term, can return to France feeling buoyed by a warm reception and unity on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France greeting people in New Orleans on Friday, where he was reminded of the bargain price of the Louisiana Purchase.

item.title: Zelensky Proposes Banning Ukrainian Orthodox Church Led by Putin Ally
item.description: Ukraine’s president called for legislation to prevent an ancient branch of the Orthodox Church, led by a Putin ally, from operating in his country, but it remains unclear how that would work.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest leading a Sunday service at a Russian Orthodox Church in the city of Kryvyi Rih, in Ukraine’s Dnipro region, in October.

item.title: Hans Magnus Enzensberger, Leading Light in German Letters, Dies at 93
item.description: Poet, essayist, journalist and social critic, he held wide influence among a postwar literary generation with works as intellectual as they were political.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Hans Magnus Enzensberger at a political event in Frankfurt in 1968. He was regarded as one of the founding literary figures of the Federal Republic of Germany.

item.title: Paul Whelan, American Prisoner in Russia, Contacts Family After Weeks of Silence
item.description: Mr. Whelan is serving a 16-year sentence in Russia on espionage charges that the United States calls politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Paul Whelan, an American accused by Russian officials of spying, is being held at a penal colony in the Mordovia region of the country.

item.title: How the ‘Price Cap’ on Russian Oil Works
item.description: The plan to curb Moscow’s oil revenues relies heavily on European shipping and insurance companies, but experts point to major loopholes.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Omsk, Russia, in November.

item.title: In Call With Putin, Scholz Vows Germany’s Continued Support for Ukraine
item.description: The call, which the Germany chancellery said lasted an hour, was the first between the two leaders since September.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in Berlin in October.

item.title: Ukrainian Embassies Targeted With Bloody Packages, Kyiv Says
item.description: The packages arrived several days after six letter bombs were mailed to offices in Spain, including those of Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez and the American and Ukrainian Embassies.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Police officers rerouted civilians after a letter bomb blew up in the Ukrainian Embassy in Madrid on Wednesday.

item.title: Population Growth Is Making Hurricanes More Expensive
item.description: The 2022 Atlantic hurricane season, which ended this week, was one of the most destructive on record.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Debris and destruction left behind by Hurricane Ian at Fort Meyers Beach, Fla. in October.

item.title: New Zealand and Australia Ponder a Lower Voting Age
item.description: As today’s teenagers will bear the brunt of tomorrow’s problems, especially climate woes, some lawmakers think 16-year-olds deserve a say at the polls.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A polling station in Auckland, New Zealand, in 2020.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Emmanuel Macron’s state visit to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Joe Biden and President Emmanuel Macron talk while walking down the Colonnade to the Oval Office at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: As Officials Ease Covid Restrictions, China Faces New Pandemic Risks
item.description: Huge swaths of the nation’s elderly remain vulnerable, scientists say, and a surge in deaths and hospitalizations may be inevitable.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Health care workers on Tuesday in Beijing, where daily Covid numbers have been at their highest since the pandemic began.

item.title: Germans Turn to Heat Pumps to Replace Gas Furnaces
item.description: The boxy machines look and function like large air-conditioners on reverse, but Germans hope they hold the key to Europe’s push for fossil-free heating.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Patrick Junker
item.media:description: A heat pump made by Vaillant, in a special room where the German company tests the device’s electromagnetic radiation.

item.title: Day 2: Your Ugly Christmas Sweater Is Beautiful in Its Own Way
item.description: The Times’s fashion director casts a discerning eye on this peculiar holiday tradition.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: ‘Constant’ Russian Airstrikes Stifle Ukraine’s Efforts to Restore Power
item.description: Even as Ukrainian workers race to restore basic services like electricity, heat and water, new Russian airstrikes send them back to the starting line.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: During a blackout in Kyiv this week.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Is China Relenting?
item.description: Plus: Kyiv in darkness, South Africa in turmoil and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Vigil attendees in Beijing commemorated the victims of an apartment fire in Urumqi, China.

item.title: EU Talks Over Russian Oil Price Cap Drag On
item.description: The negotiations over a policy intended to crimp a vital source of revenue for Russia’s war effort have been going on for more than a week.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Inside a Gazprom plant in Omsk, Russia. Ukraine’s allies want to limit Russian oil revenues as much as possible without causing a supply shock.

item.title: Ramaphosa’s Future as South Africa’s Leader in Doubt After Damning Report
item.description: An independent panel reported to Parliament that the South African president might have broken the law in a scandal over a large amount of cash hidden at his game farm that was then stolen.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, center, in 2019. He swept into office four years ago as a champion of good governance.

item.title: How Interest Rates and Inflation Differ in the US and UK
item.description: The rising cost of living can look very different depending on where you live.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: The view from Monique Foulger’s kitchen in London. She is bracing for a nearly 80 percent increase in her mortgage payments.

item.title: What Is Prince William’s Earthshot Prize?
item.description: The charity will award $6 million to five entrepreneurs from around the globe working on breakthrough climate solutions.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: Prince William founded the Earthshot Prize in 2020. This year, there were more than 1,000 nominations.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A torrent of protest videos is testing the limits of China’s censorship apparatus.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: In videos verified by The New York Times, protesters in the southern city of Guangzhou confronted police officers in helmets and white protective clothing this week.

item.title: Special Court Needed for Russian Crimes in Ukraine, EU Chief Says
item.description: The idea reflects frustration with the difficulty in holding anyone accountable in the war, and actually reaching trials in a new court is likely to be very hard.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Matt Surman
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cemetery in the Kyiv suburb of Irpin on Wednesday.

item.title: Islamic State Chief Is Dead and New One Is Picked. Both Are Unknown.
item.description: The group has been reduced from the world’s most fearsome terrorist organization to a low-level insurgency operating in limited parts of countries torn by conflict.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: American soldiers and Syrian militia members in Dayrik, Syria, near the border with Iraq and Turkey, in September.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Jiang Zemin Dies
item.description: Plus China’s censors struggle to keep up with protests.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Jiang Zemin in Hong Kong in 1998. As China’s leader, Mr. Jiang amassed influence that endured long past his formal retirement, giving him a major say in picking the current leader, Xi Jinping.

item.title: Paul Whelan, an American Imprisoned in Russia, Is Hospitalized
item.description: His family and the Biden administration are worried about his transfer to a prison hospital.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Paul Whelan at the Moscow City Court in January 2019. He was arrested in Moscow in 2018 and convicted on espionage charges in 2020.

item.title: Biden Promises Protections for Nevada’s Spirit Mountain
item.description: But the president stopped short of designating the ecologically and cultural important region, also known as Avi Kwa Ame, as a national monument.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: David Becker/ZUMA Press, Inc., via Alamy
item.media:description: Advocates want to expand protections for the Spirit Mountain area from the current 33,000 acres to encompass up to 450,000 acres.

item.title: NATO Nations Grow More Receptive to US Pleas to Confront China
item.description: After the pain of an energy crisis brought on by the Ukraine war, Europe is keen to reduce its strategic vulnerabilities to China, not to speak of other authoritarian governments.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: “The relationship for all of us is complex, as well as incredibly consequential.” Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said.

item.title: Impeachment Edges Closer for South Africa’s President, Cyril Ramaphosa
item.description: Mr. Ramaphosa, who is accused of a cover-up involving millions of dollars in cash, is up against the biggest threat of his time in power.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa in Parliament in Cape Town this month.

item.title: Why This World Cup Is Dogged by Corruption Allegations
item.description: FIFA’s system allegedly fostered bribery, but despite years of investigations and arrests it’s still in place.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Doha, Qatar, where the World Cup is being held this year.

item.title: Explosion at Ukraine Embassy in Madrid Injures One Employee
item.description: An employee was slightly injured. Ukraine ordered all Kyiv’s embassies to strengthen security after the attack.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista and Carly Olson
item.media:description: Police rerouting civilians after a letter bomb exploded in the Ukrainian Embassy in Madrid.

item.title: Physicists Create ‘the Smallest, Crummiest Wormhole You Can Imagine’
item.description: Scientists used a quantum computer to explore the ultimate escape route from a black hole.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Xi Jinping Faces Another Dilemma: How to Mourn Jiang Zemin
item.description: The former president’s death drew tributes from Chinese people at a fraught moment for the current leader, Xi Jinping, who faces widespread criticism of his harsh Covid policies.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A news broadcast featuring an image of the former Chinese leader Jiang Zemin in Beijing on Wednesday. How President Xi Jinping orchestrates tributes to him will be a test in the coming days.

item.title: Buckingham Palace Staff Member Resigns Over Remarks to Black Guest
item.description: The founder of an antiviolence support group said an aide pressed her on where she was from, dismissing Britain as an answer. The palace called the questioning “unacceptable and deeply regrettable.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: An Italian Village Hit the Jackpot. Will That Save or Destroy It?
item.description: Tiny Livemmo won nearly 20 million euros to reverse its decline. Figuring out how to spend it is a big job, but someone’s got to do it.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tiny Livemmo, in the Italian province of Brescia, won regeneration funds with a plan to become a vibrant tourist destination.

item.title: Life Without Power in Kyiv, Ukraine
item.description: Survival kits in elevators, alternative menus in cafes, flashlights and generators everywhere: This is life under Russian bombardment, when power can fail at any moment.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, on Wednesday. Officials estimate that about 1.5 million residents remain without power for more than 12 hours a day.

item.title: Vitali Klitschko, Kyiv’s Mayor, Says Russia Aims to Destroy Ukraine
item.description: Vitali Klitschko says of Moscow: “They want to destroy the country from inside.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vitali Klitschko, the mayor of Kyiv, in his office on Tuesday.

item.title: US to Pay Millions to Move Tribes Threatened by Climate Change
item.description: Two tribes in Alaska and a third in Washington State will get $25 million each to retreat to higher ground.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Emily Farnsworth/U.S. Air Force/Alaska National Guard, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The village of Napakiak, Alaska, which is losing 25 to 50 feet each year to erosion. The Biden administration has awarded it $25 million to relocate away from encroaching water.

item.title: China’s Dramatic Dissent
item.description: The unrest that has swept across the country is a rare public challenge to the world’s most powerful authoritarian government.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.media:description: Protesters in Beijing.

item.title: Inflation in Eurozone Slows as Energy Prices Ease, but Officials Remain Wary
item.description: Consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 10 percent in November, down from 10.6 percent a month earlier, the first moderation in 18 months.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: Qatar’s World Cup Narrows Rift With Saudi Arabia
item.description: The Gulf neighbors were split for years in a bitter regional dispute. Now, the glare of attention provided by the soccer tournament is highlighting their complicated reunion.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia and Qatar’s emir, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, on the sidelines of the World Cup in Doha, Qatar.

item.title: The Long Odds Facing China’s Protesters
item.description: Popular protests are more easily begun than ever before, but they are more likely to dissipate, too.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: People protesting against Covid restrictions in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Migrant Workers Fuel Protests Over China’s ‘Zero Covid’ Restrictions
item.description: Although security forces have reasserted control in many cities, rebellions against Beijing’s strict Covid rules have rocked the southern city of Guangzhou this week.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, Chris Buckley, Muyi Xiao, Joy Dong and Olivia Wang

item.title: How Cities Around the US and Abroad Approach Homelessness
item.description: New York City officials plan to remove mentally ill people from streets and subways. Here’s a quick look at how other cities and countries approach the issue of support for homeless people.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homeless encampments in Portland, Ore., in October. The city has moved to get more homeless people into mental health care.

item.title: In ‘Mandela: The Lost Tapes,’ a Veteran Journalist Finds Himself
item.description: Richard Stengel, a former Time editor who ghostwrote Nelson Mandela’s memoir, revisits their long-ago conversations for a new podcast on Audible.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Richard Stengel, a former managing editor of Time and a past under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs, has devoted a significant chunk of his career to writing about Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s first Black head of state.

item.title: A top E.U. official proposes a special court for alleged Russian crimes.
item.description: President Zelensky, his wife and Ukraine’s prosecutor general all lobbied the international community to support their proposal.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators exhumed the bodies of six men on Tuesday who were believed to have been executed by Russian forces.

item.title: Jiang Zemin, China’s Leader After Tiananmen Square Protests, Dies at 96
item.description: Mr. Jiang, a wily and garrulous politician, presided over a decade of meteoric economic growth in the post-Tiananmen era.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Michael Wines
item.media:description: Jiang Zemin in Hong Kong in 1998. As China’s leader, Mr. Jiang amassed influence that endured long past his formal retirement, giving him a major say in picking the current leader, Xi Jinping.

item.title: Ukraine welcomes a U.S. push for energy aid, saying time is of the essence.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A food stand operating on a generator in Kyiv, last week.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: China has moved to stamp out anti-lockdown protests.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Shanghai on Sunday evening. One observer of a protest there said that some students attending “maybe don’t understand how much pressure this state can pile on them.”
